posts.cooked: Hi, so since last season, I managed to get some Limelight code working and helped out a small amount. I’m now supposed to make some arm code for the 2025 robot. I believe I have some working code, but I cannot seem to get any sort of connection from the Spark Max connected to a NEO motor. I know when I connect to the Spark Max directly via USB-C, that it does in fact connect and I can open it up in the REV Hardware Client, yet when it is connected to the robot, I cannot connect to the Spark Max. I feel as though I should know the answer for this, but I am not certain.

posts.name: Kyle Burman
posts.cooked: When you connect to the spark max can you see other things on the CAN chain as well?

What method of communication are you using to connect in your robot code ( PWM or CAN )? If it’s CAN , make sure the CAN ID you see in the REV Hardware Client matches the ID in your code and that the cables are connected right. If PWM , make sure the port the motor controller is plugged into matches the port in your code. If you could post a snippet or link to your code that would be wonderful!

Looking at the CAN wires, the Spark Max Appears to be connected to the right side of the robot, with the CAN wires connecting to Krakens. In terms of Power, the NEO appears to connect to the Spark Max, and the input of power is connected to the Power Distribution Hub
I know when connected through usb-c, the rev hardware client shows the ID is 20, and I made sure in my Constants to set the Motor ID to 20

posts.name: Kyle Burman
posts.cooked: Sorry I meant in the rev hardware client, should’ve been more specific
Is there an error message that is appearing? How do you know that the motor is not connected?
I believe because the Spark Max is the only Rev Motor/Motor Controller on the robot, I believe the Krakens are CTRE so I can see those in Phoenix Tuner X, alongside Cancoders and a Pigeon 2.
Because the Spark Max is flashing off and then magenta
If it helps, here is the robot code, alongside what I have worked on, which is the code labeled Arm (Subsystem and Commands): GitHub - SmartKirb99/2025Robot

Off then magenta just means that the motor is configured as a brushless motor in coast mode. There are more status codes here . Have you actually tried running the arm motor using the controller buttons? And is the Spark Max connected to a CANivore or the RoboRIO?

link_counts.title: SPARK MAX Status LED Patterns | REV ION Brushless

posts.name: Tristan Plotkin
posts.cooked: I see from your previous replies that you are using both REV and CTRE products, I assume all CTRE product swerve? If so, do you use a CANivore for your CAN bus? The CANivore only supports CAN FD devices, meaning the Spark Max would not be supported on this CAN bus. I would try to rule this out first just in case.

Looking at the robot, the CAN wires appear to be connected to Kraken motors, which I think one of which is connected to a Pigeon 2, which that itself is connected to the RoboRio. I also noticed this error in Driver Station: ERROR ﻿﻿ 4 ﻿﻿ [ CAN SPARK] IDs: 20, WPILib or External HAL Error: CAN : Message not found Periodic Status 2

Also, just to let you all know, I will not be able to test anything until Friday, as this week, my school has final exams. My team has decided to not meet this Thursday as a result of that. So until Friday, I cannot do any testing to check. Thank you all for helping out as well!

So it seems that by connecting to the spark max while the robot was on sort of worked, I cannot test right now because somebody (not me) accidentally shorted something on the robot. So the robot is currently being worked on

Ok, I don’t know much about electrical stuff, but in terms of power, the spark max is connected to the Power Distribution Hub. I believe I was told that the Spark Max was connected to the robot’s entire system via CAN wires, which are connected to the RIO, I still have no clue as to why it appeared like they were on Coast Mode with no signal. I also remember that inherently the smart current limit was set to 80, I think, so I set it to 40, seeing as that was what a mentor suggested (It’s the min for Neo but also the max for Neo 550). That and my team is still trying to figure out stuff, there’s quite a few prototypes, so programming is quite difficult not knowing the final result of the robot

Well, seeing as I haven’t responded to this in a while, I suppose I will give an update, we have our prototype robot finished, and through a few tests. The climber arm works, the arm being a climber arm was clarified for me. But hey it works
